review.title: One-Shot Neural Cross-Lingual Transfer for Paradigm Completion
review.abstract: We present a novel cross-lingual transfer method for paradigm completion, the task of mapping a lemma to its inflected forms, using a neural encoder-decoder model, the state of the art for the monolingual task. We use labeled data from a high-resource language to increase performance on a low-resource language. In experiments on 21 language pairs from four different language families, we obtain up to 58% higher accuracy than without transfer and show that even zero-shot and one-shot learning are possible. We further find that the degree of language relatedness strongly influences the ability to transfer morphological knowledge.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In addition, most languages in the world require only about 200 computer-readable annotations (Sylak-Glassman et al., 2015) - although the morphology is easy to comment on compared to syntax and semantics. Transfer learning is a solution to this problem: it uses annotations in a highly resource-intensive language to build a system for a resource-poor language. In this paper, we present a method for the linguistic transfer of inflectional language using an encoder-decoder-recurrent-neural network (RNN), enabling the development of tools for computational languages with limited annotational data.

sections.heading: 2 Inflectional Morphology and Paradigm Completion
sections.text: Many languages have an inflection morphology, i.e. the form of a single lexical entry mutates into characteristics such as person, number, or case. The citation form of a lexical entry is called the lemma, and the collection of its possible inflections is called its paradigm. Tab. 1 shows an example of a partial paradigm; we show several forms for the Spanish verbal lemma son-ar. We can index the entries of a paradigm by a morphological keyword, e.g. the 2SgPresInd form suen-as in Tab. 1. 1. In the generation, the speaker must select an entry of the paradigm based on the context of the form. Generally, the presence of a rich inflection morphology is problematic for NLP systems, since it significantly increases the token-type ratio and thus the word form sparse. An important task in inflection morphology is the paradigmatic addition (Durrett and Deo Nerual, 2013; Ahlberg; 2014).

sections.heading: 2.1 Transferring Inflectional Morphology
sections.text: Compared to other NLP annotations, such as "part-of-speech" (POS) and designated entities, morphological inflection does not lend itself so easily to transmission. 1The joint task of SIGMORPHON 2016 (Cotterell et al., 2016a) on morphological inflection, a harder generalization of paradigm completion, showed that in many languages with neural sequence-to-sequence models an accuracy of ≥ 98% can be achieved, improving the state of the art by 10%. We can define a universal set of POS tags (Petrov et al., 2012) or entity types (e.g. coarse-grained types such as person and place or fine-grained types (Yaghoobzadeh and Protects, 2015), but the insertion is much more language-specific. It is impracticable to translate morphological knowledge from man-to-grained languages, since portuguese does not appear to be translated into Chinese transthrophologically.

sections.heading: 3.1 Encoder-Decoder RNN
sections.text: We parameterise the distribution pulse as an encoder decoder gated RNN with attention (Bahdanau et al., 2015), the state-of-the-art solution for the monolingual case (Can and protects, 2016b). A bidirectional gated RNN encodes the input sequence (Cho et al., 2014) - the concatenation of (i) the languagetag, (ii) the morphological tag of the form to be generated and (iii) the character of the entered word - represented by embedding. The input to the decoder consists of concatenations of − → hi and ← − hi, the forward and backward hidden states of the encoder. The decoder, a unidirectional RNN, uses attention: it calculates a weight for each hi decoding. Each weight reflects the meaning given to this input position.

sections.heading: 4 Languages and Language Families
sections.text: In order to verify the applicability of our method to a wide range of languages, we are conducting experiments on sample languages from several different families. Romance languages, a subfamily of Indo-European, are widely spoken, for example, in Europe and Latin America. Seeds derived from the common ancestor Vulgar Latin (Harris and Vincent, 2003) share large portions of their lexicon and inflationary morphology; we expect knowledge among them to be easily transferable. sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: In recent years, we have performed many tasks in the field of automatic speech recognition (Huang et al., 2013), parsing (Cohen et al., 2011; Søgaard et al., 2011; Naseem et al., 2012), entity recog-preprin tnition (Wang and Manning, 2014b), and machine translation (Johnson et al., 2016; Ha et al., 2016). A simple method is to translate datasets and then build a monolingual model (Fortuna and Shawe-Taylor, 2005; Olsson et al., 2005). Also, aligned corpora have been used to project information from annotations in one language to another (Yarowsky et al., 2001; Pado and Lapata, 2005). The disadvantage is that machine translation errors cause errors in the target language. Therefore, alternative methods have been suggested, e.g., to port a model trained to the target language (Shi et al., 2010).

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: Our experiments showed that information from a resource-intensive language can be used for paradigm completion in a related language with limited resources. Our analysis showed that the degree to which the source language data is helpful for a specific target language depends on its kinship. Our method resulted in significant improvements in environments with limited training data - up to an absolute 58% improvement in accuracy - enabling the use of state-of-the-art paradigm completion models in languages with limited resources.

metadata.abstractText: We present a novel cross-lingual transfer method for paradigm completion, the task of mapping a lemma to its inflected forms, using a neural encoder-decoder model, the state of the art for the monolingual task. We use labeled data from a high-resource language to increase performance on a lowresource language. In experiments on 21 language pairs from four different language families, we obtain up to 58% higher accuracy than without transfer and show that even zero-shot and one-shot learning are possible. We further find that the degree of language relatedness strongly influences the ability to transfer morphological knowledge.
